metadata.titleEn: Geochemical data of ore bearing porphyry from Xietongmen I and II deposits in the Gangdise belt, southern Tibet
metadata.description: The data are radioisotope dating data of ore bearing porphyry, major and trace geochemical data of whole rock and major and trace geochemical data of minerals. The samples were collected from the ore bearing granite porphyry of the Xietongmen Cu – Au deposit I and II in the Gangdise belt, southern Tibet. The U-Pb isotopic data were obtained by laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. The major and trace geochemical data of the whole rock were obtained by X-ray fluorescence spectrometry and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. The major geochemical data of apatite minerals were obtained by electron microprobe analysis, and the minor data of apatite and zircon minerals were obtained by laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. The geochemical characteristics and redox state of the ore bearing porphyry can be defined by the obtained data
metadata.instructions: All data are stored in Excel file. The file name "UPB. XLS" represents radioisotope data. The name of the file "wrmajtra" represents the major and trace geochemical data of the whole rock. The file name "apatite maj" represents the data of major elements in apatite. The file name "apatitetra" represents apatite trace element data. The file name "zircon tra" represents zircon trace element data.

authorList.unitEn: Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences

literatureList.titleEn: Geochemical characteristics and oxidation states of the Xietongmen ore-bearing porphyries: Implication for the genetic types of the Xietongmen No. I and No. II deposits, southern Tibet
literatureList.referenceEn: Chen, X.L., Liang, H.Y., Zhang, J., Huang, W.T., Ren, L., Zou, Y.Q. (2020). Geochemical characteristics and oxidation states of the Xietongmen ore-bearing porphyries: Implication for the genetic types of the Xietongmen No. I and No. II deposits, southern Tibet, Geological Journal, , 55，4691-4712.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the data collection methods used to obtain geochemical characteristics of mineralized porphyries in the Gangdese belt of southern Tibet?
Feature Specification.Answer: laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, zircon U-Pb isotopic analysis, X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, whole-rock major and trace geochemical data, electron probe microanalysis, major geochemical data of apatite minerals, trace analysis of apatite and zircon minerals

Quantification.Question: How many mineral samples were collected from the Xietongmen Cu–Au deposits to obtain the geochemical data?
Quantification.Answer: The original answer does not provide a specific numerical value for the number of mineral samples collected. Therefore, no refined answer can be extracted based on the given information.

Definition.Question: What are the methods used to obtain radiometric isotope dating data in the context of geochemical analysis of mineralized porphyries?
Definition.Answer: Radiometric isotope dating data are obtained through laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) analysis of zircon U-Pb isotopes.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry for zircon U-Pb isotopic analysis compare to those using X-ray fluorescence spectrometry for whole-rock major trace geochemistry in terms of precision and application in determining the geochemical characteristics and magmatic oxidation state of mineralized porphyry?
Comparison.Answer: For zircon U-Pb isotopic analysis, laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) is used, which offers high precision in dating geological samples by analyzing zircon minerals. This method is particularly effective for providing accurate radiometric ages. In contrast, X-ray fluorescence spectrometry (XRF) for whole-rock major trace geochemistry is more focused on determining the elemental composition of the rocks, providing broader geochemical data. While LA-ICP-MS is precise for isotopic dating and understanding the temporal aspects of mineralization, XRF is crucial for assessing the overall geochemical characteristics and magmatic processes influencing the mineralized porphyry. Both methods complement each other in offering a comprehensive understanding of the geochemical characteristics and magmatic oxidation state.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences on understanding the geochemical characteristics and magmatic oxidation state of ore-bearing porphyries if laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) is used extensively for analyzing zircon U-Pb isotopes and mineral trace elements?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using LA-ICP-MS for analyzing zircon U-Pb isotopes and mineral trace elements allows for precise age determination and detailed geochemical profiling, which can enhance the understanding of geochemical characteristics and the magmatic oxidation state of the ore-bearing porphyries. This method could lead to more accurate characterizations of the mineralization processes and the evolution of the magmatic systems in the southern Tibet Gangdese belt.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedures and instruments involved in collecting and analyzing radiometric age dating and geochemical data for mineralized porphyry samples in the context of southern Tibet's Gangdese belt?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Radiometric age dating data are acquired through laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) by analyzing zircon U-Pb isotopes. Whole-rock major and trace geochemical data are obtained using X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). Major geochemical data for apatite minerals are collected through electron probe microanalysis, and trace data for apatite and zircon minerals are analyzed using LA-ICP-MS.

Enablement.Question: What analytical techniques enable the precise determination of geochemical characteristics and magmatic oxidation states in mineralized porphyry samples?
Enablement.Answer: The precise determination of geochemical characteristics and magmatic oxidation states in mineralized porphyry samples is enabled by using laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) for zircon U-Pb isotopic analysis, X-ray fluorescence spectrometry (XRF), and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) for whole-rock major and trace geochemical data, as well as electron probe microanalysis (EPMA) for major geochemical data in apatite minerals. Additionally, trace analyses in apatite and zircon minerals are performed using LA-ICP-MS.
